TypeScript Workshop

le capra way

Workshop outline

  • why ts
  • basic ts
  • less basic ts
  • generics
  • redux patterns
  • react
  • ts vs the rest

Main take away

Enables moving fast and slow

  • Fast: instant feedback
  • Slow: investing in types

TypeScript basics

 1. function basics() {
 2.   const firstName1: string = "John";
 3.   const age1: number = 5;
 4. 
 5.   const firstName2 = "John";
 6.   const age2 = 5;
 7. 
 8.   interface Foo {
 9.     bar: Bar;
10.   }
11. 
12.   interface Bar {
13.     buzz: string;
14.   }
15. 
16.   const foo1: Foo = {
17.     bar: {
18.       buzz: "buzz buzz"
19.     }
20.   };
21. 
22.   interface Fuzz {
23.     fuzz: string | number;
24.   }
25. 
26.   const fuzz1: Fuzz = {
27.     fuzz: 1000
28.   };
29. }
30. 
31. function functions() {
32.   const x = () => 10;
33.   const y = (a: number) => a * x();
34.   const z: (a: number) => number = y;
35. 
36.   function hello1(): void {
37.     console.log("Hey you!");
38.   }
39. 
40.   function hello2(input: any) {
41.     console.log("Hey you!");
42.   }
43. 
44.   interface Cool {
45.     text: string;
46.   }
47.   function coolio1(): Cool {
48.     return {
49.       text: "coolio"
50.     };
51.   }
52. 
53.   function coolio2(): Cool[] {
54.     return [
55.       {
56.         text: "coolio"
57.       },
58.       {
59.         text: "coolio"
60.       }
61.     ];
62.   }
63. 
64.   const fn1: (a: string) => number = (
65.     a: string
66.   ) => a.length;
67. 
68.   type StringToNumberFn = (
69.     a: string
70.   ) => number;
71. 
72.   const fn2: StringToNumberFn = (
73.     a: string
74.   ) => a.length;
75. 
76.   interface DynamicKeys {
77.     [key: string]: number;
78.   }
79. 
80.   const dynamicKeys: DynamicKeys = {
81.     anything: 1,
82.     as_long: 2,
83.     as_it: 3,
84.     is: 4,
85.     correct_type: 5
86.   };
87. }
88.

primitive types - explicit and implicit

Function overloading

I'm lazy --> using declare

Function overloading

 1. declare function fn(x: any): any;
 2. 
 3. declare function fn(
 4.   x: HTMLElement
 5. ): number;
 6. 
 7. declare function fn(
 8.   x: HTMLDivElement
 9. ): string;
10. 
11. declare const myElem: HTMLDivElement;
12. const x = fn(myElem); // x: any, wat?
13. 
14. declare function fn2(x: string): number;
15. declare function fn2(x: number): string;
16. 
17. const z = fn2({});
18. // [ts] Argument of type '{}' is not
19. // assignable to parameter
20. // of type 'number'.
21.

overloading - same name

Type Litterals

 1. function typeLitterals() {
 2.   const firstName1 = "John";
 3.   const age1 = 5;
 4. 
 5.   const firstName2: string = "John";
 6.   const age2: number = 5;
 7. 
 8.   const firstName3: "John" = "John";
 9.   const age3: 5 = 5;
10. 
11.   const p1 = "person 1";
12.   const p2 = "person 2";
13. 
14.   const cond1 = p1 === p2; // error
15.   // '"person 1"' and '"person 2"'
16.   // have no overlap; always false
17. 
18.   const p3: string = "person 3";
19.   const cond2 = p1 === p3; // ok
20. }
21.

These are NOT equivalent

Work work!

Tasks: 1, 2,

Generics

 1. function generics() {
 2.   function arrayIdentity1(arr: any[]) {
 3.     return arr;
 4.   }
 5. 
 6.   const xs1: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
 7.   const xs2: number[] = arrayIdentity1(
 8.     xs1
 9.   );
10. 
11.   const xs3: string[] = arrayIdentity1(
12.     xs1
13.   );
14. 
15.   function arrayIdentity2<T>(
16.     arr: T[]
17.   ): T[] {
18.     return arr;
19.   }
20. 
21.   const ys1: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
22.   const ys2: number[] = arrayIdentity2(
23.     ys1
24.   );
25. 
26.   // fails
27.   const ys3: string[] = arrayIdentity2(
28.     ys1
29.   );
30.   // fails
31.   const ys4: number[] = arrayIdentity2<
32.     string[]
33.   >(ys1);
34. 
35.   function pick<T, K extends keyof T>(
36.     obj: T,
37.     key: K
38.   ): T[K] {
39.     return obj[key];
40.   }
41. 
42.   const test1 = {
43.     a: 5,
44.     b: "hello"
45.   };
46. 
47.   const a1: number = pick(test1, "a");
48.   const b1: string = pick(test1, "b");
49.   const b2: number = pick(test1, "b"); // error
50.   const b3: number = pick(test1, "c"); // error
51. 
52.   const test2 = [1, 2, 3];
53.   const test2Pop = pick(test2, "pop");
54.   const test3Pop: () =>
55.     | number
56.     | undefined = pick(test2, "pop");
57. }
58.

Anything wrong with this?

Work work!

Tasks: 3

Going crazy

...with types and redux

redux patterns

 1. export interface Action<
 2.   T extends string
 3. > {
 4.   type: T; // Discriminated Unions
 5. }
 6. 
 7. export interface ActionWithPayload<
 8.   T extends string,
 9.   P
10. > extends Action<T> {
11.   payload: P;
12. }
13. 
14. export function createAction<
15.   T extends string
16. >(type: T): Action<T>;
17. 
18. export function createAction<
19.   T extends string,
20.   P
21. >(
22.   type: T,
23.   payload: P
24. ): ActionWithPayload<T, P>;
25. 
26. export function createAction<
27.   T extends string,
28.   P
29. >(type: T, payload?: P) {
30.   return payload === undefined
31.     ? { type }
32.     : { type, payload };
33. }
34.

A plain action

redux-actions

 1. import { createAction } from "./../actions/action-helpers";
 2. import { ActionsUnion } from "./../actions/action-definitions-adv";
 3. 
 4. enum MyActionType {
 5.   ADD = "ADD"
 6. }
 7. 
 8. export const MyActions = {
 9.   add: () =>
10.     createAction(MyActionType.ADD)
11. };
12. 
13. export type MyActions = ActionsUnion<
14.   typeof MyActions
15. >;
16.

import createAction (and ActionsUnion)

ActionUnion

 1. type FunctionType = (
 2.   ...args: any[]
 3. ) => any;
 4. 
 5. type ActionCreatorsMapObject = {
 6.   [actionCreator: string]: FunctionType;
 7. };
 8. 
 9. export type ActionsUnion<
10.   AC extends ActionCreatorsMapObject
11. > = ReturnType<AC[keyof AC]>;
12. 
13. // todo - this should be moved to a flow slide
14. class Foo {
15.   serialize() {
16.     return "[Foo]";
17.   }
18. }
19. 
20. class Bar {
21.   serialize() {
22.     return "[Bar]";
23.   }
24. }
25. 
26. const foo: Foo = new Bar(); // Errors in Flow!
27.

any and all functions

Work work

Task: 4

React

 1. import * as React from "react";
 2. 
 3. interface HelloWorldProps {
 4.   name: string;
 5. }
 6. 
 7. export function HelloWorld({
 8.   name
 9. }: HelloWorldProps) {
10.   return <div>hey, {name}</div>;
11. }
12. 
13. interface HelloWorldState {
14.   counter: number;
15. }
16. 
17. class GoodByeWorld extends React.Component<
18.   HelloWorldProps,
19.   HelloWorldState
20. > {
21.   state: HelloWorldState;
22. 
23.   constructor(props: HelloWorldProps) {
24.     super(props);
25.     this.state = {
26.       counter: 0
27.     };
28.   }
29. 
30.   render() {
31.     const { name } = this.props;
32.     const { counter } = this.state;
33. 
34.     return (
35.       <div>
36.         {name}, {counter}
37.       </div>
38.     );
39.   }
40. }
41. 
42. const hello = (
43.   <HelloWorld name={"Hello you"} />
44. );
45. 
46. const goodbye = (
47.   <GoodByeWorld name={"John"} />
48. );
49.

No magic

Work work

Task: 5, 6

TS vs the rest

TypeScript vs Elm, ReasonML

  • TS is still JavaScript
  • Lower cost of implementation
  • Can eject to JavaScript

TypeScript vs Flow

  • TS has more GitHub stars?
  • TS has better IDE (VS Code)?

pro tips

  • be smart and adapt
  • any is always red flag
  • type the easy things and the hard things
  • type so that refactoring is easy
  • type so that deleting code is easy
  • have runtime checks for unknown API return types
